Reaction ΔG ads (kcal/mol) ΔH ads (kcal/mol) SO2 +Au/T1→η1-S SO2 −Au/T1 −2.8 −17.4 SO2 +Au/T1→η1-O SO2 −Au/T1 −10.7 −22.6 SO2 +Au/T4→η1-S SO2 −Au/T4 −2.7 −18.1 SO2 +Au/T4→η1-O SO2 −Au/T4 −12.4 −24.2 SO2 +Au3/T1→η1-S SO2 −Au3/T1 +6.6 −7.2 SO2 +Au3/T1→η1-O SO2 −Au3/T1 +6.4 −7.9 SO2 +Au3/T4→η1-S SO2 −Au3/T4 +5.0 −9.0 SO2 +Au3/T4→η1-O SO2 −Au3/T4 +1.1 −10.6 Nitrogen oxides and SO2 adsorption on Au/MOR catalyst: Adsorption sites, thermodynamic and vibrational frequencies. ONIOM study Anibal Sierraalta ⁎ Lenin Diaz Rafael Añez Laboratorio de Química Computacional, Centro de Química, Instituto Venezolano de Investigaciones Científicas, Apartado 21827, Caracas 1020-A, Venezuela ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +58 0212 5041774; fax: +58 0212 5041350. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Al crystallography positions do not have influence on Au species properties. ► Thermodynamically, NO adsorption is stronger on [Au]+ than on aggregates [Au3]+. ► According DFT calculations, at low Au content, the catalyst is able to adsorb SO2. Quantum chemical calculations were carried out to determine geometries, vibrational frequencies and adsorption energies of NO, NO2, N2O, and SO2 molecules on a gold-exchanged mordenite catalyst (Au/MOR). The results show that the adsorption energies are greater on [Au]+ than on [Au3]+ species. In general, the charge transferred from Au to the adsorbed molecules is higher for [Au3]+ than for [Au]+. It is shown for first time, that the SO2 adsorption is thermodynamically favored on the [Au]+ species, but not on [Au3]+ species. Therefore at low Au content, the Au/MOR catalyst could be able to adsorb SO2. Keywords ONIOM DFT DeNO x Gold Mordenite Au 1 Introduction Nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and nitric oxide (NO) are extremely harmful contaminants for human health, living species (animal and vegetable ecosystems) and the environment [1,2]. These nitrogen oxides or NO x along with N2O plays an important role in atmospheric chemistry and in the climate system. NO x and SO2 are among others responsible for the photochemical smog, greenhouse effect, acid rain and many respiratory diseases [3–7]. Some of the important sources of NO x and SO2 are the anthropogenic activities including lean-burn automobiles, oil refineries, biomass burning, etc. [6,7]. The NO x and SO2 removal from gases is possible employing catalysts. Depending on the nature of the processes, various kinds for DeNO x and DeSO x catalysts have been developed [4,6,8] among them, transition metal-exchanged zeolite catalysts. These catalysts have shown potential applications in the direct decomposition of NO x and N2O to N2 and O2 [8]. Unfortunately, transition metal-exchanged zeolite catalysts are susceptible to be poisoned by H2O or SO2 [9–11] Since 1980s, intensive researches have been performed to produce efficient DeNO x catalysts to eliminate NO x through reductive mechanisms [12–14]. To reach this goal, several studies have been carried out with different systems such as Cu/ZSM-5 [14–17], Fe/ZSM-5, [18,19] Co/ZSM-5 [20–22] and Au/ZSM-5 [23,24]. Ichikawa and coworkers [24] showed that there is a significant enhancement of the NO reduction by H2 over Au/NaY and Au/ZSM-5 catalysts. Additionally when oxygen is present; Au based catalysts have been used in CO oxidation [25,26] and in green chemistry [27]. Different oxidation states and structures for the active site have been proposed in the literature to explain the catalytic activity of Au in zeolites. Pestryakov and coworkers [28] proposed that for Au catalyst prepared by ionic exchange using mordenite (Au/MOR), the active sites correspond to Au+, Au3+ ions and charged clusters Au n d+. Ichikawa and coworkers [29] studied the Au/NaY, Au/MOR, and Au/NaZSM-5 catalysts and concluded that Au+ is the dominant active site on which the reactions take place. Sachtler and coworkers [30] using FTIR, XRD, HRAEM (high-resolution analytical electron microscopy) and CO-TPR analyzed the Au/MFI system and concluded that Au is present mainly as Au+ and Au3+. Besides the DeNO x activity, it has been reported in the literature that the Au catalysts are able to adsorb and dissociate SO2 [4,5,31] which in principle could be an indication of potential DeSO x activity. Although Au/MOR is a good catalyst for CO oxidation [32–34] and in general, the Au/zeolite catalysts are able to reduce NO x [18,23,35], the mechanism or the active species are not well known. In spite of the experimental works done to characterize the active sites [28,29,33,34], some questions remain unclear. Is the NO adsorption thermodynamically more favored than the corresponding to NO2? If N2O and NO2 are intermediates in the NO reduction, are the N2O and NO2 adsorptions more favored on isolated Au cation or on aggregates? Are there bond activations in the adsorption process? or charge transfer? Details of the manner in which the NO x , N2O or SO2 bind to the active sites or how they are dissociate by Au/zeolites, are not totally known. Adsorption studies, interaction energies as well as charge transfer studies are of particular interest for the understanding of this phenomenon. Up to our knowledge, experimental studies of SO2 adsorptions on Au/zeolites catalysts have not been reported in the literature until now. However, considering that SO2 can be dissociated on certain Au catalysts [31], it is worthwhile to investigate its interaction with Au/MOR to answer questions such as: Is the Au/MOR capable to adsorb or dissociate SO2? Under what conditions the adsorption happens? The present work was undertaken in order to understand the interaction of NO x , N2O and SO2 with Au/MOR active sites. The interaction of these gases with Au/MOR has been investigated by means of quantum chemical calculations. Herein, it presents the electronic interaction analysis, adsorption enthalpies, Gibbs free energies and frequency calculations for the adsorption on a model of Au/MOR using density functional theory. 2 Computational details and models All calculations were performed using Gaussian-03 program (G03) version RevD.02 [36] using the two-layer ONIOM2 methodology. During the optimization, only the atoms at the high level were relaxed. For the low-level calculations, the universal force field approach (UFF) was employed while for the high-level calculations, the B3LYP density functional [37] was used. LANL2DZ basis set and its corresponding pseudopotentials for H, Si, Al, and O atoms belonging to the MOR model were employed. The re-adjusted small-core relativistic compact effective potential ACEP-121 [38] with its corresponding basis set was employed for Au. For the NO, NO2, SO2 and N2O molecules the full-electron 6-31+G(d,p) basis set was used. Thermodynamic property calculations i.e. ΔG and ΔH values were done at 298.15K and 1atm. The charge analysis was performed using the natural bonding analysis, NBO method [39,40] and the APT scheme [41]. To compare with experimental IR frequencies, the calculated vibrational frequencies were scaled by 0.9632 [42]. In the framework of quantum theory of atoms in molecules (QTAIM) [43], the atomic interactions of the atoms into a molecular structure can be analyzed and interpreted in terms of the topological properties of the total molecular electronic density ρ(r). According to QTAIM, when a critical point (3, −1) or bond critical point (bcp) between the nuclei and a bond path connecting this bcp with the nuclei exists, there is an electronic interaction between these atoms. This interaction can be characterized by the values of ρ(r), ▿2 ρ(r) at the bcp, ρ bcp, ▿2 ρ bcp and the ellipticity ɛ, which is a measurement of the charge accumulation in a particular plane (σ or π character). The analysis of the ρ(r) [43] was performed using AIM2000 program from SBK-SOFTWARE [44]. B3LYP density functional was used because published results with this functional have shown an acceptable agreement with other high level theoretical methods or experimental results [45–52]. Inside MOR unit cell, there are four non-equivalent Si atom types or T sites (T1, T2, T3 and T4) [53]. The Brønsted site models for T1 and T4 sites were generated substituting the Si by one Al atom and adding one H+ to compensate the charge deficiency (H-MOR). Each site was modeled with 10 tetrahedrons (HAlSi9O30) in the high level and 264 tetrahedrons (264T) in the low level, see Fig. 1 . T1 and T4 sites were chosen because they are located at the main channel, where Au aggregates have enough space to grow. On the other hand, according to the literature [38,54], the acid Brønsted site is located preferentially at T4 followed by T2>T1>T3. Even though, stability of T1 is lower than T2, its acidity (measured as NH3 adsorption energy) is higher than T2 and similar to T4 [38]. Two cationic species were studied in this work, Au+ and Au3 +. These cationic species replace the H acidic of the H-MOR. The T1 and T4 models have been used previously by us in the CO adsorption study on Au/MOR [38]. The Au+ as well as Au3 + ions are included in the high level calculations. 3 Results and discussions As mentioned in the previous section, only two cationic species were studied in this work, A u n + , n =1, 3. These cationic species replace the H+ of the T1 and T4 sites. Tables 1 and 2 show some relevant geometrical and topological properties as well as net charges of the AuAu and AuO bonds for the Au n /T1 and Au n /T4, n =1, 3 and Figs. 2 and 3 , display the minimum energy geometries. As expected, both Au and Au3 net charges are positive and closer to unity, since, Au and Au3 occupied the Brønsted acid site. According to QTAIM results, the [Au]+ interacts with five framework O atoms at T1 site and with three framework O atoms at T4 site. The electronic density at the bond critical point and the ɛ values correlate with the AuO bond distances. In general, larger AuO distances show lower ρ and higher ɛ values. As long as ρ and ɛ are relevant parameters for describing interatomic interactions, the results of Table 1 indicate that the AuO interaction type depends on the distance. For large distances the interaction is dπ type interaction. For short distances the interaction is σ type. Table 2 and Fig. 3 show that the [Au3]+ moiety, due to its size and geometry, interacts with three O atoms at T1 (Fig. 3a) and with five O at T4 (Fig. 3b). On both sites, the [Au3]+ geometry is similar to the Au3 + free cluster geometry reported by Fielicke et al. [55]. The largest distance AuA AuB corresponds to the Au atoms bonded to the O atoms, while the shorter distances AuA AuC and AuB AuC correspond to the bond with the apical Au atom (AuC). The high ɛ value for AuA AuB bond (ɛ=0.150; 0.140) shows the high asymmetry of this bond, in comparison with the AuA AuC and AuB AuC bonds. This is a consequence of the interaction of the AuA and AuB atoms with the O atoms. Qualitatively, the interaction of the Au atoms of [Au3]+ moiety with the O atoms is similar to those found for [Au]+. As the AuO distance increases, the π character of the interaction increases. The Au atoms of the triangle base share the positive charge of the [Au3]+ moiety while the apical Au atom is almost neutral. 4 NO and N2O adsorption Table 3 shows adsorption energies (ΔE ads) enthalpies (ΔH ads) and free energies (ΔG ads) for the adsorption of one NO molecule on Au n /T1 (see Fig. 4a) and Au n /T4 n =1, 3 (for Au3 and T4 site, see figures in the supporting material). According to the results, the T site does not affect the NO adsorption. The ΔH ads, ΔG ads and AuNO distances are very similar for Au/T1 and Au/T4, as well as the angle AuNO (∠AuNO) and the NO stretching frequency ν NO. The ν NO values calculated herein, 1851 and 1841cm−1, are in agreement with the experimental values of 1820 and 1900cm−1 reported by Ichikawa and coworkers [35] for NO adsorption on Au/ZSM-5 and, the ΔH ads values are in agreement with the values reported for NO adsorption on the Au/ZSM-5, ΔH ads =−23kcal/mol [56]. To test the influence of the atomic basis sets on the ΔE ads ΔH ads and ΔG ads values, calculations with full-electron 6-31+G(d,p) basis set instead of LANL2DZ, for the atoms at the high level belonging to the MOR structure, were performed. The results reported in Tables 3 and 4 show that the change in the basis set does not have a great influence on the adsorbates geometries and the vibrational frequencies. On the other hand, the ΔE ads and ΔH ads values at 6-31+G(d,p) level are lower than the corresponding to LANL2DZ level by only ∼4–5kcal/mol. However in spite of this difference, the general trend does not change and qualitatively, the results are the same for LANL2DZ and 6-31+G(d,p). Considering the higher computational cost of the 6-31+G(d,p) basis set and the results reported in Tables 3 and 4, the LANL2DZ basis set will be used to describe and analyze the nitrogen oxides and SO2 adsorption phenomenon on the Au/MOR catalyst in this work. When NO interacts with Au3/T1 or Au3/T4, the adsorption occurs on the apical Au atom. According to the results presented in Table 3, the ΔH ads and ΔG ads as well as R AuNO and ν NO values are similar on both sites. Consequently, this suggests that the NO interaction is similar for all T sites. On the other hand, there is a higher charge transfer from Au3/T to NO than from Au/T; therefore, the ν NO values are lower for Au3/T than that for Au/T sites. The higher charge transfer is related with a lower ionization potential. It is well known that for Au clusters, the ionization potential values decrease as the number of Au atoms increase in the cluster [57]. According to our results the interaction, measured by the ΔE or ΔH values, is stronger for Au/T than for Au3/T even though there is a higher charge transfer for the latter than for the former. This fact can be understood taking into account that the interaction not only depends on the magnitude of the net charge transferred but also on the Au charge and the overlap between the HOMO of the NO molecule and the LUMO of the adsorption site. In the Au3/T systems there is an electronic rearrange after the NO adsorption. The apical atom AuC, where the adsorption takes place, is partially negative therefore there is repulsion between the negative NO and the AuC atom. This repulsion increases the AuNO distance and weakens the AuNO interaction. Beside this, due to the electronic characteristic of the [Au3]+, there is a less overlapping between the LUMO of the [Au3]+ and the HOMO of the NO molecule, than the corresponding to [Au]+ NO interaction. This factor also weakens the AuNO interaction. Table 4 shows that the N2O adsorption (see Fig. 4b) seems to follow a similar pattern presented in NO adsorption i.e.; there is no noticeable influence of the T sites and the adsorption is thermodynamically more favored on Au/T than on Au3/T sites. As in the NO case, there is a higher charge transfer from the metal to the N2O molecule in Au3/T than in Au/T which leads to lower stretching frequencies (ν NN and ν NO) for N2O adsorbed at Au3/T sites, see Table 5 . As long as ΔG ads, ΔH ads and distances are relevant parameters for describing molecular interactions, our results indicate that the N2O interaction is weaker than the NO interaction with Au/T or Au3/T systems. 5 NO2 and SO2 adsorption Up to our knowledge, experimental studies of NO2 and SO2 adsorptions on Au/zeolites catalysts have not been reported in the literature until now. However, it had been reported the extraordinary ability of Au/TiO2 catalyst to adsorb and dissociate SO2 [31]. On the other hand, it had been proposed [24,35] that the NO2 molecule is an intermediate in the catalytic cycle for the NO reduction. Therefore, it is worthwhile to investigate the adsorption of NO2 and SO2 on Au/MOR catalyst. Table 6 shows that in general, the NO2 adsorption is thermodynamically less favored than NO or N2O adsorption. For Au/T as well as for Au3/T sites, the most favored adsorption mode corresponds to η1-O mode (see Fig. 5 ) while the less favored corresponds to η2-O mode (Fig. 6 ). This is a consequence of the Au+ tendency to be linearly coordinated. In the η2-O mode, there is a higher charge transfer from the metal to the NO2 molecule probably, due to a better overlap between the NO2 HOMO orbital with the Au frontier orbital. In consequence the vibrational frequency is lower for this mode than for the corresponding η1-O or η1-N adsorption mode (see Table 5). The η2-O NO2 Au interaction destabilizes the NO2 molecule, reducing its natural ONO angle from 134° to 111°. As a consequence, the ΔH ads for this interaction is lower than the corresponding to the η1 mode where the angle (≈130°) is close to the natural ONO angle. Table 7 shows the ΔG ads and ΔH ads values for SO2 adsorption on Au/T1, Au/T4, Au3/T1 and Au3/T4 sites (see figures in the supporting material). Stable structures or minimum energy structures for SO2 η2-O adsorption mode were not found. This result point out that, the η2-O adsorption mode is not possible for SO2 at Au/T or Au3/T sites. Furthermore, the results show that for the Au3/T sites, the SO2 adsorption in any adsorption mode is thermodynamically unfavored which indicates the poor capacity of the Au3/T to adsorb the SO2 molecule. In general, the vibrational frequency for the η1-O is lower than the corresponding to the η1-S adsorption mode, as shown in Table 5. This suggests that there is a higher charge transfer from the metal to the SO2 in the η1-O than in the η1-S adsorption mode. According to the results presented in Table 7, the SO2 adsorption will be thermodynamically favored at very low Au content in the catalyst where the main species are Au+ (Au/T sites). As the Au content increases (Au3/T sites), the catalyst capacity to adsorb SO2 diminish due to the [Au n ]+ formation. This result is a consequence of the site strength. It has been shown in the literature [38] that the Au+ species are stronger soft acids than the [Au3]+ species consequently; the SO2 interaction with the Au/T sites will be more favorable than the interaction with the Au3/T sites. 6 Conclusion Minimum energy structures, adsorption energies, enthalpies and free energies for NO, NO2, N2O, and SO2 adsorbed on different sites for Au/MOR models were determined using ab initio calculations at density functional level. The most relevant features found in this work can be summarized as follows. (a) The NO, NO2, and N2O adsorption is stronger on the Au/T than on the Au3/T sites. (b) There is not a strong influence of the T site on the adsorption capacity of the Au species and therefore, the adsorption enthalpies are approximately the same for Au/T1 and Au/T4, and for Au3/T1 and Au3/T4. (c) There is a higher charge transfer to the adsorbed molecule from Au3/T than from Au/T. This is a consequence of the lower ionization potential of the [Au3]+ species in comparison with the [Au]+ species. (d) The SO2 free energy adsorption on [Au3]+, is positive while for [Au]+ is negative; this suggests that at low Au content in the catalyst, the Au/MOR could be able to adsorb SO2. Acknowledgments The authors acknowledge the financial support given by FONACIT G-2005000426 project and Mision Ciencia project. coredata.dc:description: Quantum chemical calculations were carried out to determine geometries, vibrational frequencies and adsorption energies of NO, NO2, N2O, and SO2 molecules on a gold-exchanged mordenite catalyst (Au/MOR). The results show that the adsorption energies are greater on [Au]+ than on [Au3]+ species. In general, the charge transferred from Au to the adsorbed molecules is higher for [Au3]+ than for [Au]+. It is shown for first time, that the SO2 adsorption is thermodynamically favored on the [Au]+ species, but not on [Au3]+ species. Therefore at low Au content, the Au/MOR catalyst could be able to adsorb SO2.
coredata.dc:title: Nitrogen oxides and SO2 adsorption on Au/MOR catalyst: Adsorption sites, thermodynamic and vibrational frequencies. ONIOM study
